text: I spoke specifically to a couple of

and South Asians Nepalese and
Indian markers and they described
conditions there as being pathetic and
oppressive they put it they described
working in the extreme heat in Qatar
with no proper drinking water on the
site they said they weren't able to
complain about conditions or raise any
issues of management they spoke also
about in some instances being forced to
hand over their passports which of
course we've heard in some of these
reports from human rights organizations
same stuff still going on we've got
pictures which I think relate to the

touch with them yes I am indeed I've
actually spoken to them a number of
times since and they've basically said
that the conditions have not changed
that they remain pretty much the same as
you can imagine many of them are too
afraid to speak but they have
recommended to their colleagues to get
in touch as well working on these
construction sites so I've heard from
others working there as well and we
spoke to a lot of them via whatsapp and
using chat apps which has been a good
resource for us because as I said many
of them were too afraid to speak and
what they basically said is that the
conditions that remain the same right
it's a sort of invisible way for them to
get their message over isn't it rather
than having to be seen to be talking to
the likes of you face-to-face which good
they might perceive as dangerous ana
Steve still got their foot flat to the
floor haven't they here in saying that
you know the FIFA are failing dismally
what sort of response are they offering
up at the moment yes yeah well the
Qatari government and FIFA have
responded to this the Qatari government
say the welfare of migrant workers is a

said are telling me that no improvements
have been made on the ground
FIFA themselves have responded by saying
FIFA is fully aware of the risks facing
